elements.content: By employing a variety of different aliphatic dicarboxylic acids as the secondary auxiliary ligands, six novel zinc compounds, namely, {[Zn2(mal)2­(bix)1.5]·3H2O} n (1), {[Zn2(male)2­(bix)2]­·3H2O} n (2), {[ Zn3(suc)2­(bix)4]­·2NO3·7H2O} n (3), {Zn­(glu)­(bix)]­·2H2O} n (4), {Zn­(fim)­(bix)]­·2H2O} n (5), and {Zn­(sub)­(bix)]­·3H2O} n (6) (mal = malonic, male = maleate, suc = succinate, glu = glutaric, fim = pimelic, sub = suberate, bix = 1,4-bis­(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)-benzene) have been hydrothermally synthesized and structurally characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses, and further characterized by infrared spectra, elemental analyses, powder X-ray diffraction, and thermogravimetric analyses. Compound 1 exhibits an extremely rare example of 1D rotaxane-like chain. Compound 2 features a novel 4-connected {65·8} topology. Compound 3 shows an unprecedented two-level hierarchical self-penetrating system based on unusual 2D + 2D → 2D and 1D + 2D → 3D polyrotaxane array. Both compounds 4 and 5 are comprised of undulated 2D 44-sql networks. In 4, the adjacent undulated layers are parallel interpenetrated to each other to give a 2D → 3D polycatenation framework, which further constructs a 3-fold interpenetrating pcu network through extensive hydrogen bonding. In compound 5, there are only two identical undulated layers which are interpenetrated to each other to give a 2D → 2D parallel interlocked structure. Compound 6 displays a 4-connected non-interpenetrating cds network. Structural diversity of these six complexes indicates that the conformation of bix ligand and the spacer length of aliphatic dicarboxylic anions play an important role in the assembly of different frameworks. Furthermore, the solid-state luminescent properties of compounds 1–6 have also been investigated at room temperature.

elements.content: Presented here are six novel Zn-metal−organic frameworks based on a 1,4-bis­(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)-benzene (bix) ligand and a series of rationally selected aliphatic dicarboxylic acids. The structural differences of the compounds suggest that the chemical nature of flexible ligands, especially the conformation and length of the ligands, has important effects on the resultant structures of the compounds.
elements.clean_text: Presented here are six novel Zn-metal-organic frameworks based on a 1,4-bis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)-benzene (bix) ligand and a series of rationally selected aliphatic dicarboxylic acids. The structural differences of the compounds suggest that the chemical nature of flexible ligands, especially the conformation and length of the ligands, has important effects on the resultant structures of the compounds.

elements.content: Recently, functional coordination polymers have been extensively explored for their appealing structural topologies as well as potential applications such as gas storage, magnetism, luminescence, heterogeneous catalysis, etc. In efforts to develop functional coordination polymer materials for specified properties, a number of structural and experimental factors such as coordination geometry of metal ions and ligands, pH values, metal/ligand ratio, and temperature have been found to play important roles in the construction of coordination polymers. Among many influential factors, the judicious selection of well-designed organic ligands has been proven to be one of the most effective and controllable routes in building a wide variety of open framework materials with attractive topological structures. On the basis of this synthetic strategy, plenty of organic ligands have been widely employed. Compared with the rigid ligands, flexible ligands can assume many types of conformations which offer the possibilities to form complicated and fantastic networks. Because of the conformational freedom of flexible ligands, however, it is difficult to predict the resulting structures. Therefore, much more corresponding investigations of the correlation between the conformation of flexible ligands and the final topologies of the coordination polymers need to be done and a deliberately rational design would be a long-range challenge.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Recently, functional coordination polymers have been extensively explored for their appealing structural topologies as well as potential applications such as gas storage, magnetism, luminescence, heterogeneous catalysis, etc. In efforts to develop functional coordination polymer materials for specified properties, a number of structural and experimental factors such as coordination geometry of metal ions and ligands, pH values, metal/ligand ratio, and temperature have been found to play important roles in the construction of coordination polymers. Among many influential factors, the judicious selection of well-designed organic ligands has been proven to be one of the most effective and controllable routes in building a wide variety of open framework materials with attractive topological structures. On the basis of this synthetic strategy, plenty of organic ligands have been widely employed. Compared with the rigid ligands, flexible ligands can assume many types of conformations which offer the possibilities to form complicated and fantastic networks. Because of the conformational freedom of flexible ligands, however, it is difficult to predict the resulting structures. Therefore, much more corresponding investigations of the correlation between the conformation of flexible ligands and the final topologies of the coordination polymers need to be done and a deliberately rational design would be a long-range challenge.

elements.content: Taking inspiration from the aforementioned points, five interesting entanglement coordination polymers have been obtained by us through utilizing a series of flexible N-donor ligands with different conformations as auxiliary ligands in the presence of fum2– (fumaric) as coligands. In extending our previous work, we select 1,4-bis­(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)-benzene (bix) as the flexible ligand which possesses cis and trans conformation as a result of the free rotation of two methylene groups, having been justified as good candidates for structural assembly of novel coordination polymers. Meanwhile, we also introduce six aliphatic dicarboxylic acids with different spacer lengths (Scheme ) into the Zn-bix system to explore the influence of the spacer length of dicarboxylate ligands on the structural topologies. Fortunately, we successfully obtained six new coordination polymers, {[Zn2(mal)2­(bix)1.5]­·3H2O} n (1), {[Zn2(male)2­(bix)2]­·3H2O} n (2), {[Zn3(suc)2­(bix)4]­·2NO3·7H2O} n (3), {Zn­(glu)­(bix)]­·2H2O} n (4), {Zn­(fim)­(bix)]­·2H2O} n (5), {Zn­(sub)­(bix)]­·3H2O} n (6) (mal = malonic, male = maleate, suc = succinate, glu = glutaric, fim = pimelic, sub = suberate). These compounds vary their structure from a 1D chain to a 3D framework, which show that the conformation and spacer length of flexible ligands can efficiently affect the formations of some interesting frameworks. Furthermore, luminescent properties of the compounds 1–6 are also investigated in detail.

elements.content: The bix ligand was synthesized by the literature method. All other reagents were reagent grade and used as purchased without further purification. Elemental analyses of C, H, and N were performed on an EA1110 CHNS-0 CE elemental analyzer. The FT-IR spectra were recorded on a Nicolet Magna 750 FT-IR spectrometer using KBr pellets in the range of 4000–400 cm–1. Fluorescent data were collected on an Edinburgh FLS920 TCSPC fluorescence spectrophotometer equipped with 450 W xenon light. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) were carried out on preweighed samples in a nitrogen stream using a Netzsch STA449C apparatus with a heating rate of 10 °C/min. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data of the samples were collected on a Rigaku DMAX2500 diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.154 nm) at a scanning rate of 5° min–1 for 2θ ranging from 5 to 50°.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Instrumentation

The bix ligand was synthesized by the literature method. All other reagents were reagent grade and used as purchased without further purification. Elemental analyses of C, H, and N were performed on an EA1110 CHNS-0 CE elemental analyzer. The FT-IR spectra were recorded on a Nicolet Magna 750 FT-IR spectrometer using KBr pellets in the range of 4000-400 cm-1. Fluorescent data were collected on an Edinburgh FLS920 TCSPC fluorescence spectrophotometer equipped with 450 W xenon light. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) were carried out on preweighed samples in a nitrogen stream using a Netzsch STA449C apparatus with a heating rate of 10 °C/min. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data of the samples were collected on a Rigaku DMAX2500 diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.154 nm) at a scanning rate of 5° min-1 for 2θ ranging from 5 to 50°.

elements.content: A mixture of H2mal (21 mg, 0.2 mmol), bix (48 mg, 0.2 mmol), Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O (60 mg, 0.2 mmol), NaHCO3 (33 mg, 0.4 mmol), and water (10 mL) was placed in a 23 mL Teflon liner. The resulting mixture was stirred for 30 min at room temperature, and then the mixture was sealed in a Parr autolave and kept at 100 °C for 3 days. After being slowly cooled to the room temperature, colorless prism crystals of 1 were isolated. Yield: 34% based on Zn. Anal. Calcd for C27H31Zn2N6O11 (746.36): C, 43.41; H, 4.15; N, 11.25. elements.content: Suitable single crystals of compounds 1–6 were carefully selected under an optical microscope and glued to thin glass fibers. Structural measurements were performed on a computer-controlled Oxford Xcalibur E diffractometer for compounds 1, 2, 4, 5, 6 and on a Rigaku MM-007/Saturn 70 for compound 3 with graphite monochromatic Mo–Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Absorption corrections applied to the data using the SADABS program. All of the structures were solved using the direct method and refined by full-matrix least-squares methods on F 2 by using the SHELX-97 program package. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropic thermal parameters, and hydrogen atoms attached to carbon were fixed at their ideal positions. And the hydrogen atoms of the lattice water molecules in compounds 2, 3, and 6 were not included in the final refinement. Crystallographic data and structure refinement parameters for compounds 1–6 are summarized in Table , and selected bond lengths and angles are given in .
elements.clean_text:
Single-Crystal X-ray Structure Determination of the Compound 1-6 

Suitable single crystals of compounds 1-6 were carefully selected under an optical microscope and glued to thin glass fibers. Structural measurements were performed on a computer-controlled Oxford Xcalibur E diffractometer for compounds 1, 2, 4, 5, 6 and on a Rigaku MM-007/Saturn 70 for compound 3 with graphite monochromatic Mo-Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Absorption corrections applied to the data using the SADABS program. All of the structures were solved using the direct method and refined by full-matrix least-squares methods on F 2 by using the SHELX-97 program package. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropic thermal parameters, and hydrogen atoms attached to carbon were fixed at their ideal positions. And the hydrogen atoms of the lattice water molecules in compounds 2, 3, and 6 were not included in the final refinement. Crystallographic data and structure refinement parameters for compounds 1-6 are summarized in Table , and selected bond lengths and angles are given in .

Compound 1 is an extremely rare example of a 1D rotaxane-like network. As shown in Figure a, the structure of 1 contains two Zn­(II) cations, one and a half bix ligands, two mal2– anions, and three uncoordinated water molecules. The coordination environment of Zn1 is a distorted {ZnO2N2} tetrahedral geometry, with two nitrogen donors from two different bix ligands and two oxygen donors from carboxylate groups belonging to two different mal2– ligands. In contrast, each Zn2 atom is five-coordinated and resides in a trigonal bipyramidal coordination environment. Two oxygen atoms belonging to different mal2– ligands and one nitrogen atom from bix ligand constitute the base of the equatorial plane, whereas the apical positions are occupied by O3 and O6b from two different mal2– ligands with an O3–Zn2–O6b bond angle of 177.20(16)°. For convenience, the bix ligands containing N1 and N5 are designated bix-A and bix-B, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Description of Crystal Structures

Structure of {[Zn2(mal)2(bix)1.5]⋅3H2O} n  (1)

Compound 1 is an extremely rare example of a 1D rotaxane-like network. As shown in Figure a, the structure of 1 contains two Zn(II) cations, one and a half bix ligands, two mal2- anions, and three uncoordinated water molecules. The coordination environment of Zn1 is a distorted {ZnO2N2} tetrahedral geometry, with two nitrogen donors from two different bix ligands and two oxygen donors from carboxylate groups belonging to two different mal2- ligands. In contrast, each Zn2 atom is five-coordinated and resides in a trigonal bipyramidal coordination environment. Two oxygen atoms belonging to different mal2- ligands and one nitrogen atom from bix ligand constitute the base of the equatorial plane, whereas the apical positions are occupied by O3 and O6b from two different mal2- ligands with an O3-Zn2-O6b bond angle of 177.20(16)°. For convenience, the bix ligands containing N1 and N5 are designated bix-A and bix-B, respectively.

elements.content: In compound 1, both mal2– ligands adopt bidentate (through O2–O3 or O6–O7 atom pairs at Zn2) and bridging (through O1 or O5 atoms at Zn1) modes to bind four Zn­(II) atoms, forming a [Zn4(mal)4] metallamacrocycle (Figure b right). Neighboring [Zn4(mal)4] tetramers are further linked by bix ligands in bidentate bridging modes to yield a 1D coordination polymer chain. A pair of bix-A ligands in cis-conformation cradles two Zn­(II) atoms to achieve a [Zn2(bix)2] hexagonal ring with maximum dimensions of 9.178 Å × 10.766 Å. Of particular interest, the most striking feature of compound 1 is that each [Zn2(bix)2] ring of the chain is threaded by the bix-B ligand in trans-conformation (node-to-node distance of 13.194 Å). If each [Zn2(bix)2] ring is regarded as a loop, and each bix-B ligand is regarded as a single rod, the structure of 1 can be described as an unusual rotaxane-like chain (Figure b,c). Up to now, the interesting architectures with rotaxane character are still rare. Only a few examples displaying a rotaxane or rotaxane-like structure based on 2D sheet or 3D framework are known. Therefore, compound 1 represents a novel 1D motif showing rotaxane character. Furthermore, the adjacent 1D chains are further extended into a 3D supramolecular architecture by face-to-face π···π interactions between the imidazole ring of different bix ligands (face-to-face and centroid-to-centroid distances: 3.413 and 3.475 Å for type A; 3.518 and 3.938 Å for type B) (Figure d). Additionally, the intermolecular O2w···O8 (2.665 Å) and O2w···O3w (2.857 and 2.867 Å) (Table S1 in the ) hydrogen-bonding interactions further stabilize the whole framework of 1.

elements.content: The asymmetric unit of 2 consists of two crystallographically independent Zn­(II) ions, two male2– ligands, and three bix ligands (namely, bix-A (N1–N4), bix-B (N5–N6), and bix-C (N7–N8)) (Figure a). The two kinds of Zn atoms are all coordinated with two oxygen atoms from two individual male2– ligands and two nitrogen atoms from two different bix ligands in the form of distorted tetrahedral geometry. The Zn distances are in the range of 1.996(3)–1.992(3) Å, which are in the normal range according to previously reported Zn­(II)-based carboxylates. In compound 2, three kinds of bix ligands all present a trans-configuration bridging mode and can be divided into two types, which show different dihedral angles between the imidazole rings. One type of bix ligands (bix-B and bix-C) with the dihedral angle of 0° bridges Zn1 cations into a 1D zigzag [Zn­(bix-B)­(bix-C)] n chain with the Zn···Zn distances of 14.41 and 14.60 Å. Such 1D zigzag chains are arranged in an -AAA- packing pattern in the ab plane and an -ABAB- packing pattern along the c axis to create the 1D pseudorectanglar channels (Figure b). Another type of bix ligands (bix-A) with the dihedral angles of 48.95° link the neighboring Zn2 ations into 1D [Zn­(bix-A)] n ribbons which are threaded through the pseudopentagonal channels (Figure c).

elements.content: It is fascinating that the cross-linking of two sets of [Zn­(bix)] n chains extend in three noncoplanar directions, as schematized by the rod-packings of Figure d. Contrary to the other 1D species, in which all the chains can be separated into two parts by a plane without breaking bonds, this entanglement is only disentangled by slipping off the chains. And another notable feature of this supramolecular entanglement is that each [Zn­(bix-B)­(bix-C)] n chain is alternately interwove with the [Zn­(bix-A)] n chains in an inclined plane with an angle of 67.89° (). Such an entanglement is still surprisingly rare in coordination polymers. The adjoining [Zn­(bix-B)­(bix-C)] n chains and [Zn­(bix-A)] n ribbons are subsequently bridged together by male2– ligands into a 3D coordination polymer (Figure e). Topologically, the Zn­(II) ions can be defined as a four-connected node, and the bix and male2– ligands can be considered as linkers. Therefore, the framework of 2 can be described as a 4-connected network with the Schläfli symbol of {65·8} and the vertex symbol of (6.6.6.6.­6(2).8(2)) (Figure f). This net is absolutely different from the cds network, which defines a new 4-connected topology that is unobserved according to electronic databases EPINET, RCSR, and TOPOS TTD.

elements.content: When male2– was replaced by the suc2– ligand, an unprecedented self-penetrating framework 3 based on unusual 2D + 2D → 2D and 1D + 2D → 3D polyrotaxane array was observed. The asymmetric unit consists of three crystallographically independent Zn­(II) atoms, one and two half suc2– ligands (suc-A­(O1–O2), suc-B­(O3–O4), suc-C­(O5–O8)), three and two half bix ligands (bix-A­(N1–N4), bix-B­(N5–N8), bix-C­(N9–N12), bix-D­(N13–N14), bix-E­(N15–N16)), two nitrate anions, and seven lattice water molecules. The three zinc atoms all take distorted tetrahedral geometries of [ZnN3O] or [ZnN2O2] (Figure a). Both Zn1 and Zn3 atoms are coordinated by one carboxylate oxygen atom from suc2– ligand and three nitrogen atoms from three bix ligands, while the Zn2 center is coordinated by two carboxylate oxygen atoms from two suc2– ligands and two nitrogen atoms from two independent bix ligands.

elements.content: As shown in Figure b,c, the bix-D and bix-E ligands connect the adjacent Zn1 ions in a trans-conformation into an infinite 1D chain. A pair of cis-bix-C ligands cradles two Zn3 atoms to form a [Zn2(bix-C)2] hexagonal ring with maximum dimensions of 9.33 × 11.38 Å. These [Zn2(bix-C)2] loops and the infinite Zn-bix chains are combined by cis-bix-A ligands, resulting in a 2D layer containing tetragonal mesh with the dimensions of 27.02 Å × 27.91 Å. If each Zn1 atom is considered as a three-connecting juncture and the [Zn2(bix-C)2] loops act as linear linkers, the 2D layer exhibits a 63 topology. To fill the large void space in a single layer, such two layers interpenetrate in a parallel fashion, thus generating a 2D + 2D → 2D interpenetration layer with polyrotaxane and polycatenane features (Figure a,b). Furthermore, the suc-A ligands, acting as the extra bridging molecules, connect two sets of interpenetration layers together to generate a 2D self-penetrating sheet (Figure c,d). In addition, two bix-B ligands in a cis-conformation bridge two Zn2 atoms into a [Zn2(bix-B)2] ring with maximum dimensions of 9.29 × 11.50 Å. Neighboring [Zn2(bix-B)2] loops are integrated together by suc-B ligands to construct a 1D chain containing alternating [Zn2(bix-B)2] 26-membered loops and suc-B rods, which paves the way for the unprecedented coexistence of polyrotaxane and polycatenane motifs (Figure a left). Notably, as shown in Figure a (right), the spacious nature of the single 2D self-penetrated bilayer allows those 1D chains to penetrate it. Thus, the 1D chains are entangled with the 2D stacked sheets in an inclined mode to generate an unusual 1D + 2D → 3D polythreading arrangement (Figure b). It is noteworthy that the highlighted [Zn2(bix-B)2] rings of the orange chains are threaded by the green bix-D ligands rods of the green layer. Undoubtedly, the entangled array is an unquestionable framework possessing both polyrotaxane and polycatenane characters. Finally, the suc-C ligands as linkers connect those interpenetrated chains and bilayers to construct a single self-penetrated 3D architecture (Figure c).

elements.content: In summary, the outstanding structural feature of 3 includes the exceptional coexistence of two distinct levels of self-penetration. The first level is related to 2D + 2D → 2D rotaxane-like polycatenane, and the second level is derived from a 1D + 2D → 3D polyrotaxane. Up to now, there are only a limited number of entangled arrays containing two distinct levels of entanglements. However, for these arrays, the entangled features are derived from interpenetration and polycatenation, self-penetration and polycatenation, and self-penetration and interpenetration. For compound 3, the simultaneous occurrence of two levels of self-penetration in the same crystal structure has never been reported before. Therefore, compound 3 represents the first entangled framework exhibiting two levels of self-penetration with polyrotaxane and polycatenane character.

elements.content: A better insight into such an involved framework can be accessed by the application of a topological approach. To reduce the complicated structure to simple connection nets, all Zn­(II) centers can be assigned to four-connected nodes, and each suc2– and bix ligand can be considered as linear linker. Accordingly, the whole 3D network can be simplified into a (3,3,4)-connected trinodal framework with the Schläfli symbol of (103)­(6 × 102)­(64·8 × 10), representing a new topological prototype (Figure d). Moreover, despite the nature of two levels of self-penetration in the structure, compound 3 still contains solvent accessible voids (21.7% of the crystal volume as calculated by PLATON). Free nitrate anions and uncoordinated water molecules are located in the cavities, which further consolidates the structure.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that compound 4 belongs to space group P21/c and features a 2D → 3D parallel polycatenation framework based on a (4,4) undulated sheet. The fundamental building unit of 4 contains one independent Zn­(II) cation, one glu2– anion, one bix ligand, and two lattice water molecules. Each Zn­(II) center is four-coordinated by two oxygen atoms from two bridging glu2– ligands and two nitrogen atoms from two bix ligands adopting trans conformation to constitute the [ZnN2O2] distorted tetrahedral geometry (Figure a). Along the crystallographic c axis, the bix ligands coordinated to adjacent Zn­(II) centers in zigzag and “Ω” conformations to generate a meso-helical chain with a pitch of 14.863 Å (Figure b). These adjacent meso-helical chains are extended to a 2D undulated 44 layer with the aid of the glu2– pillars (Figure c). In the layer, two bix ligands, two glu2– ligands, and four Zn atoms form a repeating rectangle grid with a side length of 10.300 × 14.181 Å based on the metal–metal distances. Because of the spacious nature and high undulation of the single 44 sheet, the rectangle voids are filled via mutual interpenetration of the adjacent sheets in parallel fashion, leading to a 3D polycatenated network (Figure d,e).

elements.content: Despite the nature of mutual interpenetration, the PLATON calculation shows that the overall entanglement still contains a small solvent-accessible void space of 11.5% of the total crystal volume that is occupied by the lattice water molecules. As anticipated, classical hydrogen bonding between lattice water molecules and carboxylate oxygens (O1···O1w = 2.744 Å, O1w···O2w = 2.749 Å, O4a···O2w = 2.759 Å, O1w···O1wc = 2.774 Å; symmetry codes: c = 3 – x, 2 – y, −z) (Table S4 in the ) was observed (Figure a). When the hydrogen bonds are taken into account, the resulting structure of 4 can be classified into classical pcu architecture, in which the acyclic water tetramer act as six-connected nodes and the glu2– and bix ligands act as linkers (Figure b,c). Rectangular apertures within a single pcu network (14.181 × 22.864 Å) allow interpenetration of two independent equivalent nets, generating a 3-fold interpenetrating 3D framework (Figure d,e).

elements.content: Compound 5 crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1̅. As depicted in Figure a, the asymmetric unit contains one crystallographically independent Zn center, displaying a slightly distorted tetrahedral geometry via coordinating to two oxygen atoms from two fim2– ligands and two nitrogen atoms from two bix ligands. The fim2– anions coordinate the Zn­(II) atoms in bis­(monodentate) bridging mode to form fascinating left- and right-handed helical chains with a pitch of 10.065 Å corresponding to the length of the a axis. These adjacent helical chains are further interconnected by bix ligands to generate a 2D sheet with (4,4) topology (Figure b). The single sheet contains large rectangular meshes with a side length of 10.67 × 13.99 Å and exhibits a highly undulating character because of the backbone flexibility of bix ligands. As observed in similar spacious (4,4) networks, the large rectangular windows and the corrugation of the single sheet allow another identical sheet to interpenetrate the grids in a parallel mode, thus giving a 2-fold 2D → 2D parallel polycatenated structure (Figure c).

elements.content: Further inspection shows that the lattice water molecules (O1w, O2w) and carboxyl groups (O2, O4) are interconnected with each other by strong hydrogen bonding to sustain the stabilization of the polycatenated double sheets. The H-bonding parameters are summarized in . Moreover, π···π interactions in compound 5 are also found between different bix ligands (centroid-to-centroid and perpendicular distances: 3.571 and 3.445 Å) (Figure d), which extend the interlocked double layers into a 3D interdigitated supramolecular architecture.

elements.content: A single-crystal X-ray diffraction study reveals compound 6 is constructed by one independent Zn­(II) cation, one sub2– anions, two kinds of bix ligands, and three lattice water molecules (Figure a). In 6, each Zn­(II) atom is surrounded by a couple of bix ligands as N-donors, and two sub2– anions as O-donors, exhibiting a distorted {ZnN2O2} tetrahedral geometry. Two kinds of bix ligands exhibit trans-configuration and act as bidentate ligands coordinated to the Zn­(II) centers to form an infinite 1D [Zn­(bix)] chain with Zn···Zn separation of 13.799 and 14.769 Å. All the 1D chains lie parallel to each other exhibiting perpendicular directions in the bc plane. And two perpendicular sets of parallel chains are superimposed along the a direction with an −ABAB– sequence (Figure b right). It is interesting to notice that the strong π···π stacking interactions between two phenyl rings of two bix ligands from adjacent perpendicular sets with the plane to plane distance of 3.732 Å and the centroid–centroid distance of 3.979 Å (Figure b left), which stabilizes the crystal structure. Additionally, each sub2– anion links the Zn­(II) atoms into a single-stranded meso-helix with a pitch of 22.358 Å (Figure c). The combination of 1D chains of [Zn­(bix)] n and [Zn­(sub)] n generates a 3D architecture (Figure d). From the topological point of view, each Zn atom can be regarded as a four-connected node, the bix ligands and sub2– anions are taken as linkers, and the 3D structure can be classified as an uninodal four-connected cds (CdSO4) network with the Schläfl symbol of (65·8) (Figure e).

elements.content: As is shown in the descriptions above, the simultaneous use of the flexible aliphatic dicarboxylic acids and bix ligand yields a series of interesting 1D, 2D, and 3D frameworks. Comparing compounds 1–6, almost all of the Zn­(II) centers are located in a four-coordinated environment, and bix and dicarboxylate ligands are linear linkers, but networks with diverse topologies are built, which indicates the length of aliphatic dicarboxylate ligands and the conformation of bix ligands are the keys to influence the final structures. The bix ligands exist in two different conformations of cis and trans in compounds 1–6. The cis-conformation is only found in compounds 1 and 3, and the rest bix ligands are all in a trans-conformation. From the previous reports, the cis-conformations always lead to the formation of closed rings, whereas the trans-conformations lead to the higher dimensional frameworks. In compounds 1 and 3, the Zn­(II) atoms are cradled by cis-bix ligands to create a 26-membered [Zn2(bix)2] loop, which favors the formation of entangled compounds with polyrotaxane and polycatenane character. As a result, 1D rotaxane-like chains and 3D self-penetrating framework composed of 2D + 2D → 2D and 1D + 2D → 3D polyrotaxane are obtained for 1 and 3, respectively. In compounds 4 and 5, the bix ligands coordinate to the Zn­(II) atoms in trans-conformation combined with glu2– or fim2– ligands to yield 2D 44-sql networks. Because of the different lengths of glu2– and fim2– ligands, the dimensions of rectangle grids in the 44-sql networks based on the metal–metal distances are different, which results in the differences in interpenetrating modes between 4 and 5. However, though the bix ligands also adapt trans-conformation, compounds 2 and 6 are both four-connected net with {65·8} topology. Because the male2– ligand is shorter than the sub2– ligand, compound 2 is simplified to a unique topology that is never found in other coordination polymers, whereas compound 6 is a usual non-interpenetrating cds network. These results show that in the self-assembly process of coordination polymers containing dual ligands, the geometries of the ligands (such as spacer length, conformation, etc.) play important roles in the final structures.

Effect the Conformation and Spacer Length of Flexible Ligands on the Coordination Polymers

As is shown in the descriptions above, the simultaneous use of the flexible aliphatic dicarboxylic acids and bix ligand yields a series of interesting 1D, 2D, and 3D frameworks. Comparing compounds 1-6, almost all of the Zn(II) centers are located in a four-coordinated environment, and bix and dicarboxylate ligands are linear linkers, but networks with diverse topologies are built, which indicates the length of aliphatic dicarboxylate ligands and the conformation of bix ligands are the keys to influence the final structures. The bix ligands exist in two different conformations of cis and trans in compounds 1-6. The cis-conformation is only found in compounds 1 and 3, and the rest bix ligands are all in a trans-conformation. From the previous reports, the cis-conformations always lead to the formation of closed rings, whereas the trans-conformations lead to the higher dimensional frameworks. In compounds 1 and 3, the Zn(II) atoms are cradled by cis-bix ligands to create a 26-membered [Zn2(bix)2] loop, which favors the formation of entangled compounds with polyrotaxane and polycatenane character. As a result, 1D rotaxane-like chains and 3D self-penetrating framework composed of 2D + 2D → 2D and 1D + 2D → 3D polyrotaxane are obtained for 1 and 3, respectively. In compounds 4 and 5, the bix ligands coordinate to the Zn(II) atoms in trans-conformation combined with glu2- or fim2- ligands to yield 2D 44-sql networks. Because of the different lengths of glu2- and fim2- ligands, the dimensions of rectangle grids in the 44-sql networks based on the metal-metal distances are different, which results in the differences in interpenetrating modes between 4 and 5. However, though the bix ligands also adapt trans-conformation, compounds 2 and 6 are both four-connected net with {65⋅8} topology. Because the male2- ligand is shorter than the sub2- ligand, compound 2 is simplified to a unique topology that is never found in other coordination polymers, whereas compound 6 is a usual non-interpenetrating cds network. These results show that in the self-assembly process of coordination polymers containing dual ligands, the geometries of the ligands (such as spacer length, conformation, etc.) play important roles in the final structures.

elements.content: Considering that coordination polymers with zinc metal centers usually exhibit excellent luminescence properties and can serve as good candidates for potential applications in photochemistry, chemical sensors, the fluorescent properties of 1–6 were investigated in the solid state at room temperature (Figure ). To get an insight into the origin of the emissions of these compounds, the photoluminescence property of the free bix ligand was also measured. Upon excitation at 340 nm, the bix ligand displays a weak emission maximum at ca. 410 nm, probably attributable to the π* → n or π* → π transitions. As depicted in Figure , excitation at 360 nm leads to intense violet fluorescent emissions with the maxima at 420 nm for 1, 434 nm for 2, 438 nm for 3, 426 nm for 4, 424 nm for 5, and 418 nm for 6, respectively. The resemblance between the emissions of compounds 1–6 and the free bix indicates that the emissive behavior property is ascribed to π* → n or π* → π transitions within the molecular orbital manifolds of imidazolyl and phenyl rings of bix moieties. In comparison with the free bix, the emissions of all compounds exhibit slightly red-shifted which may be caused by different coordination environments around the metal ions. In addition, the luminescence intensities of 1–6 times are stronger compared with the free bix ligand. This kind of luminescence behavior may be attributed to the metal perturbed intraligand emission state like other d10 metal compounds and other intermolecular interactions such as π···π packing lying in interpenetration, interdigitation, or simple packing of layers. The dicarboxylate ligands almost make no contribution to the fluorescent emission of as-synthesized compounds since the emission bands of the dicarboxylate ligands originated from the π* → n transition are very weak compared to that of the π* → π transition of the bix ligand.

To get an insight into the origin of the emissions of these compounds, the photoluminescence property of the free bix ligand was also measured. Upon excitation at 340 nm, the bix ligand displays a weak emission maximum at ca. 410 nm, probably attributable to the π* → n or π* → π transitions. The resemblance between the emissions of compounds 1-6 and the free bix indicates that the emissive behavior property is ascribed to π* → n or π* → π transitions within the molecular orbital manifolds of imidazolyl and phenyl rings of bix moieties. In comparison with the free bix, the emissions of all compounds exhibit slightly red-shifted which may be caused by different coordination environments around the metal ions. In addition, the luminescence intensities of 1-6 times are stronger compared with the free bix ligand. This kind of luminescence behavior may be attributed to the metal perturbed intraligand emission state like other d10 metal compounds and other intermolecular interactions such as π⋅⋅⋅π packing lying in interpenetration, interdigitation, or simple packing of layers. The dicarboxylate ligands almost make no contribution to the fluorescent emission of as-synthesized compounds since the emission bands of the dicarboxylate ligands originated from the π* → n transition are very weak compared to that of the π* → π transition of the bix ligand.

elements.content: The thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were carried out on crystalline samples of 1–6 to study the thermal stability of these compounds. The results show that all compounds are stable in air at ambient temperature, which makes them potential candidates for practical applications. The thermal behaviors of 1–6 are presented in . For compound 1, the weight loss in the range of room temperature to 100 °C corresponds to the departure of three lattice water molecules (obsd 7.12%, calcd 7.24%), and the remaining framework is thermally stable up to 200 °C, at which the framework begins to collapse. For 2, the weight loss corresponding to the release of lattice water molecule is observed from 30 to 110 °C (obsd 5.94%, calcd 6.07%). The decomposition of the anhydrous compound occurs from 270 °C. TGA curve of 3 shows that the first weight loss from 90 to 170 °C corresponds to the loss of the lattice water molecules (obsd 8.03%, calcd 7.72%). The compound then reaches a plateau with no further weight loss up to 270 °C. Upon further heating, the host framework begins to decompose. Compound 4 lost its two lattice water molecule from 80 to 130 °C (obsd 7.74%, calcd 7.66%). A gradual weight loss from 310 °C corresponded to removal of the organic components. In the case of compound 5, the TGA curve shows an initial weight loss from room temperature to 100 °C, corresponding to the removal of two lattice water molecules (obsd 7.37%, calcd 7.23%), and the departure of the organic components occurs from 310 °C. Compound 6 releases its lattice water molecules gradually from room temperature to 130 °C (obsd 9.46%, calcd 10.19%). The decomposition of the residual composition occurs at 300 °C forming an unidentified product.

elements.content: In order to confirm the phase purity of these compounds, the powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) experiments were carried out for 1–6. As illustrated in , the main peaks of experimental spectra of 1–6 are basically consistent with their simulated spectra, confirming the phase purity of the compounds.

elements.content: In summary, the introduction of a series of aliphatic dicarboxylic acids with different spacers into the Zn-bix system resulted in six compounds ranging from 1D rotaxane-like chain (1) to 2D → 3D or 2D → 2D polycatenation structure based on 44-sql network (4, 5), 3D framework with new topology (2), two-level hierarchical 3D self-penetrating framework (3), and non-interpenetratingcds networks (6). The structural differences of the compounds suggest that the chemical nature of organic ligands, especially conformation of bix ligand and the length of the dicarboxylates, have important effects on the resultant structures of the compounds. Thus, this work represents a nice example of the auxiliary ligand controlled polymeric architecture construction and further enriches the crystal engineering strategy for the formation of the predetermined architectures and desired properties.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, the introduction of a series of aliphatic dicarboxylic acids with different spacers into the Zn-bix system resulted in six compounds ranging from 1D rotaxane-like chain (1) to 2D → 3D or 2D → 2D polycatenation structure based on 44-sql network (4, 5), 3D framework with new topology (2), two-level hierarchical 3D self-penetrating framework (3), and non-interpenetratingcds networks (6). The structural differences of the compounds suggest that the chemical nature of organic ligands, especially conformation of bix ligand and the length of the dicarboxylates, have important effects on the resultant structures of the compounds. Thus, this work represents a nice example of the auxiliary ligand controlled polymeric architecture construction and further enriches the crystal engineering strategy for the formation of the predetermined architectures and desired properties.

Synthesis of {[Zn2(mal)2(bix)1.5]⋅3H2O} n (1)

A mixture of H2mal (21 mg, 0.2 mmol), bix (48 mg, 0.2 mmol), Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (60 mg, 0.2 mmol), NaHCO3 (33 mg, 0.4 mmol), and water (10 mL) was placed in a 23 mL Teflon liner. The resulting mixture was stirred for 30 min at room temperature, and then the mixture was sealed in a Parr autolave and kept at 100 °C for 3 days. After being slowly cooled to the room temperature, colorless prism crystals of 1 were isolated. Yield: 34% based on Zn. Anal. Calcd for C27H31Zn2N6O11 (746.36): C, 43.41; H, 4.15; N, 11.25. Found: C, 43.76; H, 3.89; N, 11.07. cln_elements.content:
A better insight into such an involved framework can be accessed by the application of a topological approach. To reduce the complicated structure to simple connection nets, all Zn­(II) centers can be assigned to four-connected nodes, and each suc2– and bix ligand can be considered as linear linker. Accordingly, the whole 3D network can be simplified into a (3,3,4)-connected trinodal framework with the Schläfli symbol of (103)­(6 × 102)­(64·8 × 10), representing a new topological prototype (Figure d). Moreover, despite the nature of two levels of self-penetration in the structure, compound 3 still contains solvent accessible voids (21.7% of the crystal volume as calculated by PLATON). Free nitrate anions and uncoordinated water molecules are located in the cavities, which further consolidates the structure.

Structure of {Zn­(fim)­(bix)]·2H<sub>2</sub>O}<italic toggle="yes"> <sub>n</sub> </italic> (<bold>5</bold>)

Compound 5 crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1̅. As depicted in Figure a, the asymmetric unit contains one crystallographically independent Zn center, displaying a slightly distorted tetrahedral geometry via coordinating to two oxygen atoms from two fim2– ligands and two nitrogen atoms from two bix ligands. The fim2– anions coordinate the Zn­(II) atoms in bis­(monodentate) bridging mode to form fascinating left- and right-handed helical chains with a pitch of 10.065 Å corresponding to the length of the a axis. These adjacent helical chains are further interconnected by bix ligands to generate a 2D sheet with (4,4) topology (Figure b). The single sheet contains large rectangular meshes with a side length of 10.67 × 13.99 Å and exhibits a highly undulating character because of the backbone flexibility of bix ligands. As observed in similar spacious (4,4) networks, the large rectangular windows and the corrugation of the single sheet allow another identical sheet to interpenetrate the grids in a parallel mode, thus giving a 2-fold 2D → 2D parallel polycatenated structure (Figure c).

Thermal Stability and Powder XRD Patterns

The thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were carried out on crystalline samples of 1–6 to study the thermal stability of these compounds. The results show that all compounds are stable in air at ambient temperature, which makes them potential candidates for practical applications. The thermal behaviors of 1–6 are presented in . For compound 1, the weight loss in the range of room temperature to 100 °C corresponds to the departure of three lattice water molecules (obsd 7.12%, calcd 7.24%), and the remaining framework is thermally stable up to 200 °C, at which the framework begins to collapse. For 2, the weight loss corresponding to the release of lattice water molecule is observed from 30 to 110 °C (obsd 5.94%, calcd 6.07%). The decomposition of the anhydrous compound occurs from 270 °C. TGA curve of 3 shows that the first weight loss from 90 to 170 °C corresponds to the loss of the lattice water molecules (obsd 8.03%, calcd 7.72%). The compound then reaches a plateau with no further weight loss up to 270 °C. Upon further heating, the host framework begins to decompose. Compound 4 lost its two lattice water molecule from 80 to 130 °C (obsd 7.74%, calcd 7.66%). A gradual weight loss from 310 °C corresponded to removal of the organic components. In the case of compound 5, the TGA curve shows an initial weight loss from room temperature to 100 °C, corresponding to the removal of two lattice water molecules (obsd 7.37%, calcd 7.23%), and the departure of the organic components occurs from 310 °C. Compound 6 releases its lattice water molecules gradually from room temperature to 130 °C (obsd 9.46%, calcd 10.19%). The decomposition of the residual composition occurs at 300 °C forming an unidentified product.
